Award.AwardTitle: Digitization PEN: Mollusca and Arthropoda Biodiversity in the Colorado Plateau Region
Award.AbstractNarration:
The insect collection at the Museum of Northern Arizona (MNA) spans nearly 100 years, focusing on the iconic Grand Canyon ecoregion and surrounding landscapes. Many specimens were collected at springs - critical ecosystems that support unusually high levels of biodiversity and unique species compared with the surrounding landscape. Through this award 120,000 well-documented insect specimen records and 1,000 high-resolution images will be digitized and contributed to the InvertEBase Thematic Collection Network (TCN). MNA staff will conduct three workshops on specimen identification and imaging, and will train and mentor students, including those from under-represented groups, to learn about museum curation, imaging, data management, and biodiversity research. The MNA will also present an interactive exhibit on the biodiversity of invertebrates on the Colorado Plateau and Grand Canyon. Designed to appeal to all age groups, the exhibit will consist of photographs and information about the region's most compelling species, with taxonomy, distribution, evolutionary history, ecological roles, and conservation status.

The data digitized through this project will fill critical gaps on species geographic ranges and contribute taxa currently not included in InvertEBase, with a representation of Odonata, Mantodea, Blattodea, Hymenoptera, Coleoptera, and non-insect terrestrial Arthropoda (Myriapoda, Arachnida and Crustacea). Specimens include records of rare, endangered, and undescribed species. MNAInverts, an online relational database, will serve as a platform to facilitate identification and georeferencing of specimens, and to streamline quality control procedures. Georeferencing of collection localities will increase their value for range mapping and biogeographical studies. The resource will include annotated, stacked, high resolution images of exemplar specimens from the region. To facilitate identification, important morphological character states essential for diagnosis at the species level will be noted. The project will advance public and scientific understanding of the complexity and importance of aquatic and terrestrial invertebrates to the ecological integrity of the Southwest. The MNA's contribution of occurrence data and images will augment the representation and distribution of Mollusca and Arthropoda in the InvertEBase TCN and will be shared with iDigBio (www.idigbio.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Goals and Description

The Museum of Northern Arizona (MNA) in Flagstaff has one of the most complete collections of invertebrates from the Grand Canyon region on the southern Colorado Plateau, but little of the collection had been databased or made available to the public and the scientific community. MNA applied for and received support for an NSF PEN PTE Federal Award to better present these remarkable collections. The goals of this grant were to: 1) database at least 120,000 invertebrate specimens from the Grand Canyon region in the Museum of Northern Arizona (MNA) collections; 2) photograph at least 1,000 of those specimens, particularly the rare and endemic taxa; 3) develop an exhibit on the invertebrates of the Colorado Plateau; and 4) provide students with opportunities to assist in museum curation procedures that support biodiversity research. Here we present the Project Outcomes Report for this grant.

Methods and Results

Goal 1 - Data Entry

Quality Control: The MNA invertebrate collection contains more than 350,000 specimens collected across the Colorado Plateau, as well as across the Intermountain West in North America. This collections contain specimens collected more than 70 yr ago. However, during which time much taxonomic re-evaluation has taken place. We ran a query on a total of 10,711 of our names records against a downloaded ITIS list of scientific names, updating the taxonomy and spelling on more than 6,000 specimens.

Data Entry: We entered collections data on each specimen into an in-house Access database compatible with DarwinCore information standards, and after rigorous quality control, we migrated the data into a Symbiota-based data portal, and then conveyed it into IDigBio. IDigBio is a publically available biodiversity information management system. In all, we submitted data on 165,871 specimens in 111,359 cases (occurrences), including at least 3,845 taxa among 3,481 species in 1,825 genera in 434 families of invertebrates. At least 43,997 (39.5%) cases and 64,200 (38.7%) specimens were identified to the species level. A total of 7,742 non-Insect invertebrate specimens were uploaded into the publically available Chicago Field Museum?s InvertEBase, primarily included Mollusca, Annelida, Aranae, Diplopoda, Chilopoda, and crustacean Decapoda and zooplankton. Through the course of this project we reviewed and updated georeferencing data on 109,558 (98%) of the total specimens databased, among the nearly 6,000 collection locations.

 

Goal 2 -  Imaging

Imaging invertebrate specimens was coordinated by Co-PI Gary D. Alpert, who with his several students and staff, imaged a total of 1,240 (1.1%) pecimens, typically with dorsal, lateral, head, and label habitus images provided, except for Lepidoptera (photographed by Tom Cheknis), for which combined dorsal and ventral wing images were provided. Students and staff organized images to facilitate automated image uploading for subsequent transfer into InvertEBase and IDigBio. Imaged specimens are documented using a green photography tag for future identification, and are placed back into the MNA collections.

 

Goal 3 - Outreach

Dr. Stevens and Dr. Alpert delivered more than 50 lectures and other presentations during the course of this grant, providing talks to high school, university, general public, and scientific audiences. Although Covid-19 pandemic curtailed much visitation to MNA during the latter half of this project, Dr. Alpert developed an MNA exhibit on honey pot ants from northern Arizona, and Dr. Stevens developed an e-book on dragonflies and damselflies of the Grand Canyon region, for dissemination to Colorado River guides who reach more than 27,000 visitors/yr.

 

Goal 4 - Education and Professional Training

Over the course of the project, MNA employed three graduate student, two vetran or minority undergraduate students, and several recently graduated students, including Native American and women to assist on a part-time basis. All of these individuals greatly increased their knowledge of invertebrate taxonomy and information management through the project.

 

Chicago Field Museum of Natural History (FMNH) Coordination

FMHN coordinated MNA?s PEN subaward through administrative oversight on the digitization and imaging of MNA?s terrestrial and aquatic mollusks and arthropod specimens from the Colorado Plateau. FMNH staff arranged and supported the identification and databasing of 165,871 terrestrial, with aquatic mollusk specimen identification by Dr. Stephanie Clark (Australia), and species identification of Diplopoda specimens by Dr. P. Sierwald.  FMNH collection manager Dr. J. Gerber arranged the mollusk identification and transportation of specimen samples to Australia. As part of the subaward, FMNH advanced the georeferencing of its own Colorado Plateau mollusks specimen records from the Four Corners states.

 

Acknowledgements

The MNA and Co-PIs Stevens and Alpert deeply appreciate the support of the NSF and the assistance of the students and staff who made this project a success, particularly Ms. Jeri Ledbetter, MGIS.
